nodes.bodyText: Why are we grouping by so many fields here and below? This can't be good performance or functionally correct.

In v2 timescaledb doesn't like existing transactions query in getTransactionsOuterQuery() and getOneTransaction().
The migrations error out on all the added columns with
ERROR:  column "t.charged_tx_fee" must appear in the GROUP BY clause or be used in an aggregate function

I can circle back to see if there are other options. Also once it's setup the performance testing task can verify the impact on the transactions query

The migrations error out

The migration shouldn't error out as this is a REST API query not run during migration. You mean that the REST API query errors when invoked by a user, right?
Yeah sorry, not the migration, actually REST API queries.

Not sure how these are working with Postgres 9.6 but timescale is enforcing the requirement of select column to be in a GROUP BY clause or be used in an aggregate function
I believe as we're using it having them in the group by doesn't change the results, but I'll have to look into any performance hits

I'm not a fan of these domains as they're PostgreSQL specific, they obfuscate the underlying type when looking at a particular table schema, their implementation is not easily discoverable without digging through past migrations and we're not using the features that might make them worthwhile like constraints.
Recommend removing as long as it's still compatible with importing from the old data.

This reduces duplication since everything else can be handled by the flyway migrations.

nodes.bodyText:
Timescaledb needs explicit setting when the data type is an integer
For integer types, the chunk_time_interval must be set explicitly, as the database does not otherwise understand the semantics of what each integer value represents (a second, millisecond, nanosecond, etc.)

Default is 7 days which is the 604800000000000 above.

nodes.bodyText:
Not yet, I could add this as a task in the performance testing side.
It really comes down to traffic on the tables and how deterministic they are.
We could account for high TPS in a week and configure for that but it doesn't say for instance what type of transactions and how say file_data will grow vs token
Those might require more analysis
Given we won't be immediately deploying we should have some time to get it right before we can't modify migrations.
Consequently I could also make default_chunk_time_interval and default_chunk_id_interval placeholders so the actual sql code doesn't need changing.
Also it is possible to update the value however it only affects data going forward and not previous data. See https://docs.timescale.com/latest/api#set_chunk_time_interval

nodes.bodyText:
Will look into which tables warrant this but note the current limitations - https://docs.timescale.com/v2.0/using-timescaledb/limitations#distributed-hypertable-limitations. Also, I believe you can only use 1 additional space to distribute across and achieve multi dimensional splits.
Although, splits across shards and realms may not necessarily be what you want.
To capitalize on the parallel computation you'd want the distribution to match the grouping of your queries e.g. by entityId or transactionType, or timestamp in the case of balances etc.
Since we're not operating in multi shards/realms yet can't say how often you'd be pulling across those and whether their optimization is necessary beyond indexing.

There's a bit of a challenge implementing this outside of k8's where multiple pods each with a single timescale-ha container is started up.
Data nodes are required prior to the  create_distributed_hypertable  command.
However attempting to add data_nodes results in
 ERROR: add_data_node cannot run inside a transaction block

Such nodes can't be added within a transaction of which each flyway migration is.

nodes.bodyText:
Comments are mixed up here. We can't do hyper tables since address_book serves as a foreign key for address_book_entry and timescale db doesn't support that - Hypertables support all standard PostgreSQL constraint types, with the exception of foreign key constraints on other tables that reference values in a hypertable.
error: foreign keys to hypertables are not supported

I can however make address_book_entry a hyper table if we do expect more traffic this way.
In terms of cons I haven't come across any yet since they've designed the use and management of hyper tables to be as easy as normal tables.

nodes.bodyText: Why would freeze_default be a good pick? You're supposed to pick a segmentby with a secondary column or columns that are used a lot in queries. It says generally that's primary keys or other columns in indexes. Should this be token_id or maybe treasury_account_id? We query more on token_id so that is preferable.
This was a mistake, agreed it should be token_id.
deleted is a poor choice. I think fk_entity_type_id would be best.

Indeed, we'd more often query by entity type that whether the entity was deleted or not.
Meant to circle back on some of these. Will update to fk_entity_type_id
segmentby = entity_id
Should probably be realm num and topic num since we use those in queries
This should be payer_account_id as that is the more frequently accessed field.
I anticipate type will become more often used. Especially as we recently added that query. I'll use both

It looks like the default timescaledb.compress_orderby is already set to the timestamp column in descending order. Thus, it would be better to leave off the hardcoded value and let it use the default if possible.
True, will remove
